üöÄ üëç
üöÄ

- [x] JPA: `SQLIntegrityConstraintViolationException` is not an instance of `RuntimeException`, so cannot be passed to the built-in ex. translation utilities ... ending up with a too generic` DataAccessException`
- [x] JDO: On unique constraint violation, we get a `NucleusDataStoreException` that translates to `JDODataStoreException` that does not translate to `DataIntegrityViolationException`
- [x] DefaultJdoDialect has no `SQLExceptionTranslator` set, so relies on the JDO provider's native exception translation
- [x] Datanucleus: On unique constraint violation, wraps a `NucleusDataStoreException` with an `IllegalArgumentException` which obscures further translation attempts
- [x] Find the right place where to put the ex. translation logic (that is, translate anything we catch to _Spring's_ `DataAccessException` hierarchy). Could give the `TransactionService` a second change. At least any (Apache Isis) _Interaction_ should make its calls to the persistence layer through the `TransactionService`. This should even hold if within an _Action_ user code is executed that uses _Transactional Spring Proxies_ under the hood that bypass any Apache Isis logic, but we should be able to intercept exceptions at the outer most `TransactionService.callTransactional(callable)` call, even if just participating in an already existing transaction.
- [ ] But then don't let `EntityFacet`(s) do any of the ex. translation stuff, just propagate exceptions as they are.
- [x] Spring's JPA integration, on _unique constraint violation_ throws an Exception only when the Spring managed transaction gets committed, which properly propagates through the `JpaDialect` for translation. However, with Spring's JDO integration, the  Exception is thrown before the Spring managed transaction gets committed, which later does not propagate through the `JdoDialect` for translation. This breaks symmetry and makes it hard to reason on where to put the exception interception logic, that does the translation.

Thanks for your contribution!

I think its save to assume, that https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ISIS-1678 can already be considered resolved. The `VirtualClock` was only introduced lately. And has a different use-case within the framework than the previous `Clock` had. I'd rather not move it.

Hope you don't mind if I close this PR without merging. Needless to say its much appreciated seeing PRs and people that want to help getting tasks done. Thumbs up!
Oh @ErnoViitanen-LUT - and by the way, if thats your first PR ever. Cool stuff, keep going!
Cool stuff, thanks a lot!

Hi @jmhupanen - I tried my best for over an hour, could not get it working. I now moved this stuff into a branch and reverted the merge to 'master'. If you like you can pick it up again and file a PR against https://github.com/apache/isis/tree/ISIS-471-pin.bookmark

However, I feel we might also regard this one as a **won't fix**, since our focus for the remaining year will be to conquer new territory with the _Vaadin Viewer_.

Let me know what you think.
@andi-huber Ok, that's fine. I'll look into that at some point, if I have time, and file a PR if I can find a fix.
Just to clarify what I meant: maybe we can just close this issue (ISIS-471) as a **won't fix**. Unless you care and want it fixed.
Also I must admit, I don't know this feature very well. I don't even know what this issue (ISIS-471) is about. Bookmarks should be kept throughout a user session anyway, why pining?

Yes, I think this can closed as a **wont't fix**. As I understand it, the reason for pinning the bookmarks is to prevent them from being removed from the bookmarks list by automatic cleaning algorithm. My intention was to implement it by ignoring the pinned bookmarks so that they are not counted as removable bookmarks by the algorithm.

Hi Juho,
if you feel like you'd like to contribute to the framework further, then
join our slack channel and have a discussion first with us first as to what
you'd like to work on.
Thx
Dan

Hi @joonatan-r - From a first glance, looks very promising. Your code comments help me quite a bit to understand the intent. I'll need some time to actually test it out (by this week).

As this is the 3rd PR within a few day against Apache Isis, I wonder why of a sudden, we get so many code contributions. And are there expected to be more?

Also my apologies, that presumable quite a bunch of (still) open Jira tickets potentially can be closed as 'won't fix'. Hence, as @danhaywood already commented on the previous PRs, we encourage you to coordinate with us before working on a ticket. That should prevent waste of time and energy. However, fixing ISIS-1922 is highly appreciated.

Best ways to coordinate with us are, either comment on the Jira tickets in question, or join our Slack chat, where I assure you we have a very welcoming community. See the contact section of our official site for details: https://isis.apache.org/#contact

Hi @andi-huber ! This PR is a part of a course project where we had to make a pull request to an open source project. The other PRs are most likely from other students from this course, so it's possible that there will be some more. Thank you for the informative comment!
I see, well good choice! Thanks for letting me know.

Hi @MNummila - thanks for the contribution. I do have some specific comments on your particular PR (down below). As this is in the context of a school course project, its unfortunate, that we missed the opportunity to help you (the participants) with picking individual open tasks and successfully contributing to these. Unfortunate, because we want you to succeed and not waste your time and energy. See also [1].

[1] https://github.com/apache/isis/pull/393#issuecomment-783168781

For this PR, I need to double check first, whether we can use to new logos. But you need to remove the changes to the pom.xml and also the job that integrates with sonar cloud. We already have sonar cloud integration for the Apache Isis project, which is hosted here [1]. Reason being, that we (the project commiters) cannot use github secrets with the main Apache projects. (We don't have the privileges to manage secrets here.) The sonar analysis is published at a daily basis, see [2].

The code (test) coverage currently seems broken, we had it working some months ago, but yet failed to find time to fix that.

[1] https://github.com/apache-isis-committers/isis-nightly
[2] https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=apache_isis

Hi @jbampton - I'm sorry, the 'master' branch changed in the meantime, as currently docs are getting revised regularly. I'm happy to merge your changes, but I'd need you to first resolve any conflicts.
Sorry for rejecting this one. Seems opinionated to me.

Hi @joonatan-r  - thanks for that one! üöÄ

@andi-huber  - this is a sketch of user impersonation ("run as") that I had in mind.  Note that it is stateful, using the HttpSession to hold onto.

In theory this impersonation capability could be used and exposed by the core framework, but (for now) I've only surfaced it in the context of secman.

Thanks for this one. But please no Sonar integration here!

We already have sonar cloud integration for the Apache Isis project, which is hosted here [1]. Reason being, that we (the project committers) cannot use GitHub secrets with the main Apache projects. (We don't have the privileges to manage secrets here.) The sonar analysis is published at a daily basis, see [2].

[1] https://github.com/apache-isis-committers/isis-nightly
[2] https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=apache_isis

I'm very sorry to say, we have just started to phase out the bootstrap-datetimepicker. Meaning, its unlikely that I will go through the process of reviewing your contribution.

If all goes well, we'll have a more modern replacement (tempusdominus), stemming from this PR https://github.com/apache/isis/pull/495 as also tracked via https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ISIS-2617. However, its still work in progress.
